title: 107_s1656
content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Benefits Administration Improvement Act of 2001". The Veterans Benefits Administration is responsible for processing claims for veterans compensation and pension. Concerns have been raised about the accuracy of claims processing, despite previous reports of a 95 percent accuracy rate. A new accuracy measurement system called the Systematic Technical Accuracy Review revealed discrepancies in 1998. The Veterans Benefits Administration found that initial reviews of veterans claims were accurate only 64 percent of the time in 1998 and 2000. With a potential 30 percent workforce loss by 2003, adequate training for claims adjudicators is crucial to ensure efficient processing. More aggressive steps are needed to process veterans claims accurately and timely to prevent delays in providing compensation and pension benefits. In 2001, delays in providing veterans with compensation and pension benefits were evident. The expected appeals processing time for a claim was 621 days, and the backlog of pending work at the Veterans Benefits Administration was 533,029 claims as of September 2001. Improvement of processing of veterans benefits claims. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a plan within 90 days of this Act's enactment to improve the processing of veterans' compensation and pension claims. The plan should include mechanisms for better training of claims adjudicators and employee accountability standards to ensure thorough initial reviews of claims. The plan must include mechanisms for improving data collection and management to identify errors in claims adjudications and implement a system for reviewing. The plan must include mechanisms for improving data collection and management to identify errors in claims adjudications and implement a system for reviewing examinations, implementing a system for reviewing claims processing accuracy, evaluating the impact of the Training and Performance Support System on claims processing, and setting quantifiable goals for each mechanism. The Secretary must consult with veterans organizations and other parties to develop the plan, implement it 60 days after submission, and can modify it with a 30-day notice to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary must submit reports every six months to assess the implementation of the plan developed with veterans organizations. The reports will evaluate whether the goals set forth in the plan are being achieved. The Secretary will implement the plan using funds from the Veterans Benefits Administration for each fiscal year.
